abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though, institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Key lessons address the
            need for: 1) government agencies to avoid direct involvement
            in commercial operations, rather, involve itself only in
            regulatory aspects, provision of technical back-stopping,
            and resolution of technical problems with wide implications
            for the industry. Commercialization should be left to the
            private sector, including assistance to beneficiaries
            regarding procurement, management, marketing, and
            operations; 2) complex project design, and back-up support
            to reflect beneficiaries' abilities, i.e., the scope of
            operation, engineering, and organizational requirements must
            be within targeted beneficiaries; likewise, the intensity of
            involvement of site management, must reflect the
            beneficiaries' capabilities; 3) appropriate policies,
            and regulations to guide aquaculture development, backed by
            effective institutions, capable of addressing social,
            technical, and environmental problems, such as displacing
            existing fishermen, or users of the resource, disease
            problems, or effluent disposal; 4) realistic sequencing of
            project developments, outlining that in the absence of a
            completed technical, and organizational design by the
            proposed start-up date, the first two years of
            implementation, should be dedicated to preparing target
            beneficiaries, through pilot trials, and, completing all
            engineering, and organizational plans; and, 5) institutional
            capacity, backed by qualified, skilled staff to ensure
            resolution of problems, and timely implementation.
            Similarly, technical qualifications of Bank teams should
            ensure comprehensive planning, and supervisory standards.
